p.add: BUREAU OF APPOINTMENTS, FEB 4 1902 Department of State.
CHIEF CLERK, FEB 4 1902 Department of State.

div1.p: Third Ass't Secretary, of State Department, Washington, D. C.

Dear Sir,- I had the pleasure to receive on the 27th., inst. notice through you of my appointment as United States Minister Resident and Consul General to Liberia. I accept with a great deal of pleasure the appointment and shall do everything in my power to represent properly the Government of the United States, of which I have the honor to be a citizen and shall do everything in my power to protect the interests of my country. I enclose the oath of Office after being duly executed and also money order for passport. My bond has been forwarded under separate cover. I thank you for any courtesies extended and beg to remain, Sincerely yours, J. R. A. Crossland M. D.
THOS. J. AKINS, Chairman. E. C. ROWSE, Treasurer. C. P. WALBRIDGE, Vice-Chariman. A. F. SHRINER, Secretary.
Republican State Committee. 1900. NATIONAL COMMITTEEMAN. R. C. KERENS.

p.add: BUREAU OF APPOINTMENTS, FEB 19 1902 Department of State. Acknd Form To Feb 10 1902

div1.p: Third Ass't Secretary of State Department, Washington, D. C.

Dear Sir,- I thought my bond had reached you several days ago, but through mistake it was sent back to St. Joseph. Please find enclosed my bond for the Liberian Mission. I thank you for any aid and all courtesies extended.
Yours respectfully, J. R. A. Crossland. M. D. United States Minister Resident and Consul General to Liberia. 813 Francis Street, St. Joseph MO
Department of State, Washington, June 17, 1890.
Miss Winifred Miller, P.O. Box 121, Newcastle, Maine.

Sir: In reply to your letter of the 14 instant, I have to inform you that your enquiries may be addressed to Ezekiel E. Smith, Minister Resident and Consul General of the United States, Monrovia, Liberia.
I am, Madam, Your obedient Servant, Sebellon A. Brown Chief Clerk.
Hayier, Cape Palmas, July 30th 1890
Mrs. E. A. Miller
Dear Madame ! We are in possession of yours date on the 4th of June.
Your husband always told me, he wish to see his home once more, he tried hard to sell his premises, but he could not find a buyer for it. so he had to stay here.
We are very glad to hear that you have confidence in us, be sure, we will do our best, we can.
We intend to sell the Estate of your husband, in May already, but a Gentleman with name Alfred H. Dent had a claim against the farmland, with coffee lures.

Your husband leased the farmland, 2 1/2 Acres in the year 1882 from Mrs Catherine Beam and Mrs. Mariah Dent. Mr. Alfred H. Dent, a son of Mariah Dent had the original lease of the 2 1/2 Acres of farmlands, on which your husband wrote, that the farmland should

transfered to Catherine Beams after his death, but this lady died 4 years ago, our opinion is, the farmland belonging still to the Estate of your husband, but the Alfred H Dent, asserted now, the farmland with Coffee lures belongig to him, because he is a brother of Catherine R. Beams. The quarterly count willl decided in next month, who the farmland belonging too.
Enclosed we beg to hand you, the copies of the lease and also a copy of your husband's last will.
Further please receive enclosed a certificate of your husband's death.
Your husband did not thought he was going to die, as we wrote you last, he only caught a bad cold and fever came to that gave him the death.
He did not left any word for you or your Children, because he did not thought he would leave this world forever.

We wrote you last, already, the Masons buried our firend, on the graveyard at this place, there was several hundred, people at the funeral of our friend, and also the military, at was a sorrowful day for

every one in this place, became nearly very one like your husband and our friend look in Cape Palmas on Account of all the goodness he has done here (and Your husband told his housekeeper, Mrs Tubman, whenever he should died here in Cape Palmas, she should have a double coffine made for him and we did so. Hope you will receive the enclosed papers carred, re remain, Respectfully Yours
Enclosures of A. M. Miller Estate { and and R. H. Gibson
Albarman Esq No. 1. Dr Sir please pal M. A. Sbrina A. M. amount of $5.00/00 not made to Yours truly Rosedole Aellellillen Jun 21/90

Albarman Esq No 2 Dr Sir: please put the M. A. the amount of $5.00/00 made
Yours Truley Rosedole Aellellillen June 21/1890
Good to Mr. Howard Quin $220 L V Food Hengies25 $2.45 Aellellillen Mch. 15/90
Mr. E. March you will put the 20 pacts to take not him
Mr E. March y the incts to the
Paid 1 M. P. Ael 1. M Poul 50 cts 50
Emil Warncke. No. 5 To J. W. Gibson & Co Dr Digging a grave for Capt A. M. Miller --- $350 &A. E. No Payment said J. W. Gibson
A. M. Miller To to making a pair pants 2 waist coat one coat for the arn't 5.00 $5.00 Recd Payment Harper April 14th '90 Maria Tippett

Mr E Warncke dear sir pay most shrper for washng out A. M. Miller acts 1 month washing $300 here month is up and I send her to you for her pay she shall not draw anything since she to wash yours truly M.A. Tubman
